sessiontitle: Art directing posts, sustainably
shortdescription: Beautifully designed longform articles are a hot topic right now but making them work efficiently and at scale is still a hard problem to solve. At Vox Media we have been building and refining longform journalism and art directed posts for years in a way that we can do a lot of big things at a large scale without putting a strain on our designers and developers. This talk will go into the evolution of our art directed posts at Vox Media and our process around them.
whoisthissessionfor: Designers and developers working on longform journalism.
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: design, longform, workflow, sustainability, repeatability, process

sessiontitle: Before we can fix the product, we need to redesign the newsroom itself
shortdescription:
Most newsrooms don't employ developers. In the lucky places with developers who are allowed to work on news projects, these journalists have a litany of common complaints: nobody understands what I do, nobody understands how databases/the internet/computers work, nobody respects how much time it takes to do this kind of work well. 

There are a lot of reasons for this that we won't be able to solve in an hour, but one legacy we need to overcome is the firmly entrenched organization and management structure of the newspaper itself. For 100 years, reporters sat together with their colleagues who covered the same beat. They reported a story, wrote it up and handed it to an editor who read it. He (almost always a he), edited it, demanded a photo or chart to illustrate it, and then handed it to the copy desk to fix typos and place on a page in the next morning's paper. Repeat for another 40 years until you drop dead at your desk. 

Obviously, nearly everything about our readers and our industry has changed dramatically in the past three decades, but our newsroom structures are remarkably unchanged. In some places, there may be a separate "digital" wing lashed on to the side of the org chart, or a "real-time" desk that handles web production. In many newsrooms, reporters report (and tweet and shoot video...), write and hand their product off to someone else to put on the web and in print. They are utterly divorced from doing anything online outside of a rigid CMS.

As journalist-developers, we know how to build apps for the web. We can visualize data and design engaging user experiences on tablet or mobile. In this session, I'd like us to talk about how we can redesign the newsroom itself to upend our clunky workflows pegged to Sunday's newspaper instead of today's news online. 

If you were the editor of your average major metro daily, how would you redraw your organization to make this work?
*How can we redesign our newsrooms to bring news developers into the reporting process at the beginning and to help everyone else master new skills? 
* Should we adopt Ben Welsh's philosophy that we ought to train web producers to become news devs and not just SEO-experts and explainer explainers? 
* Should we follow Scott Klein's model of making every developer a reporter, designer and data expert?
* How many AMEs do you really need? 
* Should web producers sit together or with the copy desk and paginators? Should they be in the same room/floor/building/state as reporters and editors? 
* What are the jobs that really need to be done here?

This exercise is about more than just rearranging deck chairs. Together, we can wipe the slate clean and design a newsroom that builds skills throughout the organization and forces people to think smarter about the internet as a primary medium rather than an afterthought.
whoisthissessionfor: People tired of 1960s org charts dictating 21st century news coverage.
anyprerequisites: It would be helpful, but not necessary, to have spent some time in a print newsroom.
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: newsrooms, organizations, redesign, developers, designers, managers, producers, journalism

sessiontitle: Human-driven design: How to know your users and build just what they need
shortdescription:
How do you decide what to build? What does your process look like before you write a line of code? How do users’ needs, desires, skills, and workflows inform how you imagine your solutions and refine them along the way? How do you invite users into your process and be sure that your finished work meets their expectations? 

And, how can you do all this and also be the creative visionary type who says “hey, they asked for a faster horse-drawn carriage but instead we built them a car”?

Let’s kick around questions like this, and talk about how we build innovative tools for journalists that meet users’ needs on their own terms. We’ll share how we identified the types of journalists we wanted to serve through Census Reporter, then researched, designed, reached out, cajoled, built, took criticism, reworked, and ultimately made a tool that serves up a complex data set with a simple interface. And then we want to hear about your process. How do *you* plan what *you’re* going to build next?
whoisthissessionfor: developers; designers; beat reporters

sessiontitle: Building Exoskeletons for Reporters
shortdescription:
Beat reporters are the great treasure of the modern newsroom. Sadly, many of our digital projects start and end with editors. I propose that we take some time to discuss practical methods for outfitting our beat reporters with robotic exoskeletons -- digital tools that make a beat reporter stronger, faster and smarter.

And then we should build some.
whoisthissessionfor: Developers; beat reporters; people who love police scanners
anyprerequisites: Curiosity; a deep and abiding love for the beat reporting system

sessiontitle: Building Smart Newsroom Tools: How A Culture Can Make or Break Your Internal Tools
shortdescription:
If you build the world's best tool -- but your newsroom isn't ready for the tool, can't find time to use the tool, doesn't understand the tool, or can't share learnings from the tool, then what's the point?

In this interactive workshop, we'll talk about how to integrate the people from your newsroom into the development process so that you launch your product with enthusiastic and optimistic supporters. We'll brainstorm strategies, talk about UX principles and sketch out ways to create a product launch that will be successful from the start.
whoisthissessionfor: everyone, but particularly folks who work at the intersection between tech and the newsroom
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: UX, workshop, culture, newsroom, analytics, apps

sessiontitle: Closing the Gaps: Let's Identify the Holes in Open Data, Then Fix Them
shortdescription:
There are some crucial tools and datasets that really need to exist, but don't. Address normalization is a crapshoot. Getting text out of PDFs is terrible, and it's not getting any better. It's impractical to share, manipulate, or analyze enormous datasets. Municipal geodata has to be obtained, individually, from each municipality. And so on. Anybody who works with open data has their own pet peeve.

Let's have a gripe session about things that are terrible, and then let's figure out how to make those things stop being terrible. The US Open Data Institute has the resources and the mandate to start addressing these problems, but we want to solve the important problems.
whoisthissessionfor: data mavens

sessiontitle: CMS roundtable discussion
shortdescription:
At first, my idea was to compile a list of elements that would go into an ideal CMS, but that didn't make sense because everyone needs different things. How about we go around, describe a problem, and then spend a few minutes discussion solutions. If we're lucky, we'll walk away with some best-practices for how to solve some common problems. Some sample problems from my mind (your mind may differ):
* How do I get my IPTC/EXIF data into my cms?
* How do I get my cms to label my images as Creative Commons?
* How do I make sure my pages are cacheable?
* How do I get edit-in-place?
* How do I integrate ad networks?
whoisthissessionfor: Developers and users of CMSesses.

sessiontitle: Cool Data, Bro
shortdescription:
But what's the story? I appreciate beautiful design, but data viz sometimes makes my eyes glaze over (or I'm too impatient to decipher it). Plus, I like a good story. 

Let's think beyond the infographic and talk about numbers narratives! (i.e. How to trick people like me into caring about numbers.)

This'll be an informal conversation. I'll show some things I've seen or worked on. It'd be cool if you did the same! Maybe even bring a story you're kicking around.

Also, graduates of this session will exchange their figurative "news nerd" badges for literal "news person" buttons.
whoisthissessionfor: People ready to kick the "news nerd" label to the curb

sessiontitle: Data Processing Pipeline Show & Tell
shortdescription:
DocumentCloud is only one of many examples of data processing pipelines in the pursuit of journalism. There are many other examples, open source (Census Reporter, PANDA, Fech) and proprietary (http://datadesk.latimes.com/posts/2013/12/natural-language-processing-in-the-kitchen/ ), large to small (medicare reimbursement data to daily arrest records)

Rather than talking about the extract, load, transform workflows in abstract, lets talk about what makes your (or someone else's) processing pipeline interesting! Were there special considerations around how the data was gathered? Any unique constraints on how the data needed to be analyzed or presented? Was the data so large that custom code and tools were necessary.
whoisthissessionfor: Those who work with data

responseidentifier: Al Shaw, Jue Yang, and Ian Dees
sessiontitle: Finding and presenting stories with raster data
shortdescription: Online mapping is going through a quiet revolution. When we first started putting interactive maps on the web, we were confined to a single toggle between Google's political and secret-sauce "satellite" view. Our tools were confined to GDAL, Google Earth and the NASA satellites. Today, there's a dizzying array of both tools and sources for raster data. Mapbox's Cloudless Atlas turns NASA's new Landsat 8 imagery into a gorgeous mosaic. Startups like Planet Labs and Skybox are deploying whole fleets of imaging satellites attached to easy-to-use APIs. How can (and should) we use this data and these tools in our reporting? What uncovered stories are literally hiding in plain sight being photographed every day? What strategies and algorithms should we use to make this imagery quantifiable? How do we combine the numerous frequency bands available in these sensors to best tell our stories? Finally, how do we present our findings? Let's discuss how raster data can elevate environmental reporting in an era when our environment is in rapid flux.
whoisthissessionfor: environmental reporters, map geeks, news apps developers, designers, scientists
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: maps, satellites, Landsat, raster imagery, environmental journalism, accountability journalism

sessiontitle: Handguns and Tequila: Avoiding Data Disasters
shortdescription:
There’s a quote attributed to Mitch Ratcliffe: “A computer lets you make more mistakes faster than any invention in human history–with the possible exceptions of handguns and tequila.”

One of the dangerous aspects of using data in journalism is the ability to do things with drastic consequences to your reporting without realizing it. (If you do something like this, of course, you hope to find it before you publish.) Just because computers are efficient doesn’t mean they don’t still need solid reporting and editing around just about everything they do.

So with that said, what should you watch out for when you or your reporters are working on a data-driven story? What mistakes are especially easy to make, and what can you do to prevent them or at least notice them before it’s too late?

Unlike a lot of other beginner data-journalism sessions common at conferences, this one would include absolutely NO code! This session would be focused on the concepts and consequences at a level that helps you ask the right questions of the people actually running your data analysis.
whoisthissessionfor: Beginners and their editors

responseidentifier: Mike Dewar, Nik Hanselman, and Jacqui Maher
sessiontitle: Hands-on: Wrangling live data the easy way with Streamtools
shortdescription:
How do you deal with LIVE data? How do you explore it, use it, and shape it into something useful? Streamtools provides a friendly interface that lets you explore live sources of data without having to perform complex infrastructure tasks. 

This workshop will introduce the basics of using streamtools:
interrogate live sources of data
build systems to track, aggregate and learn from various sources of data
import / export processing patterns and explore the streamtools API
hook into existing systems and create new streams of data

all from within a browser-based graphical interface!
whoisthissessionfor: News application developers, hacks/hackers, data analysts
anyprerequisites: bring your computer. (Dan/Erin: is it too much to add this optional prereq? "golang, if you want to hack on streamtools" we'll be linking to the latest binary ppl can download otherwise.)

sessiontitle: How NOT to Skew with Statistics: Drafting, Data Bulletproofing, and Tools for Well-*Developed* Stories
shortdescription:
There's always a lot of press-stress about interactives that are misleading and skew the data they are intending to represent. There's also a million ways that different newsrooms homebrew the bulletproofing process, and plan for how to present information with maximum integrity. How do modern news orgs navigate deceptive data and manage to provide critical readings of complicated information? 

This will be a session about ways that statistics can be charted and plotted and how to make sure that we prep our data appropriately for interactive projects. We'll also run through process models that we might adopt to make fact-checking and peer review an open and organization-agnostic process. Beyond citing sources and licensing intents to prove validity, we'll talk about how we package information in an interactive story and the protocols for making sure that honest representation is clear and concise in the various vocabularies we use to communicate the news. 

Have some things to contribute, tools to solicit feedback on, or just want to listen in and learn? Join us; everyone will walk away with a stack of resources and new things to try. Promise.
whoisthissessionfor: everyone, developers, data journalists, journalists, people
anyprerequisites: Experiences, tools to share would be awesome
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: versioned news, drafting, data journalism, data vetting, bulletproofing

sessiontitle: How to diversify the pipeline of journo-coders
shortdescription: The need for more diversity in journalism, specifically in web/coding/tech teams, is indisputable. Let's talk solutions and find tangible things we can do and encourage others to do to make a difference. What's worked for people who have had success? What can we try with our next mentee, hire, or opportunity to recommend a speaker? For newsrooms to actually become more diverse, everyone needs to contribute: hiring, managing, promoting, mentoring, teaching, and just generally creating a culture that is welcoming and open.
whoisthissessionfor: Anyone who knows diversity is a challenge that our industry is facing and wants to work on solutions.

sessiontitle: Interactives at the end of the world
shortdescription:
In a 2006 Washington Post editorial, referring to carbon emissions reduction, Bill McKibben wrote, "there are no silver bullets, only silver buckshot." It's a sentiment that reflects the complexity of anthropogenic climate change, and it's relevant to any of us that are thinking about how to use our skills towards a climate change project. Rather than feel overwhelmed and paralyzed by the scale of the issue, we can try to address pieces of the problem from different angles, and do so over time. As designers and developers with a public audience, we can make an impact on public and political perceptions of climate issues in more accessible ways than scientists alone can achieve. But how can we best spend our energy doing so?

When considering projects...
* What topics are the most pressing to address, in international or domestic contexts?
* What are some small projects that can be tackled by individuals or smaller teams?
* What audiences are we best catering to: the general public, politicians, children?
* What existing tools can be used to accelerate the production of climate-related interactives?
* What tools don't already exist but should?
* What are some great tapped or untapped datasets?

Considering the decades of research on climate change...
* In psychological, sociological, and media studies research on climate communication, how does the public respond towards particular patterns, phrases, and design decisions when expressing climate change concepts?
* What are the best existing examples of local and global climate stories and visualization, and what can we learn from them? What are the worst and why?
* What communication lessons can be learned from climatologists, urban planners, and governmental organizations in their understanding of how populations will be affected by changing conditions? How can we improve on their techniques of expressing domain knowledge?
whoisthissessionfor: concerned citizens

sessiontitle: Make your own security blanket
shortdescription: Computer security is a hard problem, and the tools we have to deal with it are confusing, highly technical, and often broken. If you work in news -- in any capacity -- this is a dangerous situation. There are always sensitive sources whether they are informing on a local police department or from a warzone or on national security matters. So, lets talk about communicating securely, why security is so important, and how our community can help.
whoisthissessionfor: Everyone who works in news.

sessiontitle: Make your team of developers braver through DevOps (God help us all)
shortdescription:
For the last couple of years, the word DevOps has been thrown into every conversation...even when it shouldn't have been.

DevOps is actually a very easy concept, with a whole lot of advantages to not just your development team but to your entire organization. DevOps is not a set of tools, nor a specific process, but instead DevOps is a culture and workflow.

We'll talk about what DevOps is, what it isn't, and how I've helped implement it at the Obama 2012 campaign and Mozilla Foundation.

I promise there will be animated gifs.
whoisthissessionfor: Developers, Product/Project Managers, Ops

sessiontitle: Making things happen with small teams
shortdescription: For the small news dev team (including teams of one), resources are often scarce and your time can be split between a number of roles. Let's talk about the best strategies to make the most of what we have without feeling hopeless or falling prey to burn out. Let's gather with our small-team peers (even if you're just getting started!) and share what's helped us stay productive, what *doesn't* work, ideas for proving worth to potentially skeptical colleagues, and practical tools to maximize our capabilities.
whoisthissessionfor: Small teams and small organizations, devs, designers, team leaders

sessiontitle: Mapping influence in investigations
shortdescription:
Influence mapping tools like LittleSis, Poderopedia and even Gephi have been around for a while and applied in many different contexts. But while these tools have been used to create nice network diagrams and profile pages, they aren't really a meaningful part of journalistic workflows yet. In this session, I want to brainstorm ideas on what is needed to make social network analysis tools not just a fancy form of visualising the outcomes of investigations, but an actual tool to manage evidence, ask journalistic questions and derive unexpected insights.

To kick off the discussion, I'll quickly introduce the connectedAfrica project, which maps out politically exposed persons in African countries. I'll also demo the grano toolkit, which Code for Africa is building in collaboration with the KnightLab, Poderomedia and others to collect, structure and analyse journalistic network data.
whoisthissessionfor: newsdevs, journos and researchers

sessiontitle: Mobile is the future / mobile sucks / the future sucks
shortdescription:
Mobile is the future. There can't really be any argument on that point now - mobile audience shares just keep on rising and if your audience isn't over 50% mobile yet, it will be soon. There's only one problem: developing for mobile sucks.

You have to deal with small screens. And big screens. The Android browser. Chrome on Android (yes, they're different). Chrome running on iOS. Safari running on iOS. Got your page working great on all of those? OK. What happens when someone turns their phone sideways? Thought so.

We'll discuss some of the useful tools you might not know about - remote debugging, the iOS Simulator, and better ways to use the Android simulator. We'll talk about some gotchas - like iOS7's weird browser UI and it's minimal-ui meta tag, or new CSS units like 'vh' and 'vw'. But also think of it as a group therapy session - bring a problem you've encountered before and we'll discuss how to solve it. Bring the horror stories of that time a mobile browser behaved in a way you didn’t expect and couldn't understand. We'll get through this together.
whoisthissessionfor: Developers that have worked with mobile before, but aren't "mobile developers"
anyprerequisites: Ideally you'll know the basics of mobile/responsive - CSS media queries and so on.
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: mobile, iphone, android, css, javascript, therapy

sessiontitle: New Frontiers in Javascript: The Browser at the Bleeding Edge
shortdescription:
Once a second tier environment, the browser has become the de facto standard for innovative applications. Complex distributed systems, high-fidelity 3D games, and rich, real-time editorial tools have all moved to browser-based solutions. But with an expanded domain, comes expanded demands and new difficulties. This session is intended to workshop some of the new and experimental tools aimed at creating optimized, complex browser applications.

We will discuss and workshop the uses, applications and rough edges around experimental, new technologies such as (but not limited to):
- React.js and its new rendering paradigm
- Functional Reactive Programming, especially its manifestations in Elm and, to a lesser extent, RxJS
- Functional languages with a Javascript backend such as GHCJS, Clojurescript, Idris, and Faye
- Alternative browser concurrency models (such as CSP) as provided by Clojurescript and ES6 generators
- Sweet.js and the concept of accelerating Javascript evolution through macros
whoisthissessionfor: Front-end developers that want to push JS to new limits, lovers of new technology, Javascript skeptics
anyprerequisites: Some knowledge of Javascript. Any interest at all in functional programming.
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: Javascript, react.js, frp, functional reactive programming, rxjs, elm, ghcjs, clojurescript, idris, faye, csp, es6, generators, sweet.js

responseidentifier: Gabriela Rodriguez and Jeremy B. Merrill
sessiontitle: Opening your code for newsrooms to use
shortdescription: This session will be a place to discuss tips and best practices to release the code you are writing, for newsrooms to use. It will be related to writing code as well as steps to release the code (examples, documentation, tutorials). The outcome will be a guide on how to open your software.
whoisthissessionfor: everybody

responseidentifier: Brian Abelson, Michael Keller, and Stijn Debrouwere
sessiontitle: Own Your Analytics.
shortdescription:
Almost all analytics software has an API and API clients. We'll show people how they can get data from Google Analytics and a few other APIs (GA Live, ChartBeat, Facebook Insights, Google Alerts, Bitly, etc.) as well as how they can get social data from utilities like Pollster, SharedCount.com or the "raw" social APIs. We'll then show them how best to organize and join all of this information to create interesting new dashboards, textualizations, visualizations, email reports that respond to events, and even new metrics.

We'll have example code ready for all of these systems so people
(1) get a quick overview of how these APIs work and can then
(2) very quickly move on to actually *doing* things with it.

At the end of the session, participants should have a clearer path to controlling their own analytics data, integrating numbers from multiple sources, creating more meaningful metrics, and (hopefully) making meaningful decisions informed by data.
whoisthissessionfor: People dissatisfied with their current analytics provider(s) or looking for a way to integrate data from many different analytics providers.

sessiontitle: Releasing data trapped in PDFs with your community
shortdescription: Sometimes we have PDF documents that are impossible to convert into text with the common tools. If you have a scanned PDF then it may be hard to find an OCR tool that can convert it. And you need the data to process, visualize and use in your investigation. Then we can use the power of your community. Call your community to crowdsource the conversion of PDF documents. That is what we did with the senate spendings at La Nacion. The project is called VozData and the software that created it is called Crowdata. This session is going to be a techy one about how to use crowdata in your newsroom.
whoisthissessionfor: programmers, hackers, techies, courageous journalists

sessiontitle: Sartre Was Wrong: Hell is Data About Other People
shortdescription: Data about people is all around us. It also comes in countless varieties of formats, with "unique" identifiers that aren't or no identification system at all. We all have to deal with people data in our reporting and applications. How do we do it? What are the best (and worst) tools and libraries? What about determining gender? This session is designed to unearth the practices that we use for handling personal identifiers and to find the best ones or to figure out where the unmet needs are, and try to start solving them. Open to any and all languages and platforms.
whoisthissessionfor: Developers, reporters, even other people
anyprerequisites: Being a person, knowing people's names.

sessiontitle: Style Guides: codifying your common interface decisions
shortdescription:
Over 6 months ago, we started working on a style guide for our interactive projects, and only a few months ago actually started using it. With it, we have seen the productivity of our small team increase significantly from day one of its use.

Style guides are one of many ways to codify common decisions that save time. But with coding these decisions, there are still costs associated with creation, maintenance, overriding, and more. In this session, I will talk about how and why we made our style guide from design, organizational, and technical perspectives and what the pitfalls have been and will be into the future. Also, we will take a look at other style guides made by other news organizations.
whoisthissessionfor: Coders (designers and engineers) and project management types
anyprerequisites: Basic knowledge of HTML/CSS/JS (or how web pages work)

sessiontitle: The Hitchhiker's Guide to Datasets
shortdescription:
There are great stories just waiting to be mined from big, traditional datasets, but it can be scary to dig in when you don't know the jargon and nobody left a map. Take the American Community Survey: hundreds of tables full of fascinating data, but before you start reporting with confidence, you need to know about summary levels and table universes, the difference between the 1-year/3-year/5-year releases, and why you should never compare, say, 2012 3-year data against 2011 3-year data.

I can get you caught up on those concepts ... but then I couldn't tell you a *thing* about FEC data. You know who can, though? Derek Willis. And Jake Harris knows AP election data so well he’s taken all the excitement out of the load process. We all know the secrets and traps hidden in the datasets we've spent the most time with; I'll bet you know something just like this that no one else at SRCCON does. So let's start making a guide together by talking about the data each one of us knows well.

For this session, we'll cover the basics of:

* Census data from the American Community Survey: Joe Germuska and Ryan Pitts
* Campaign finance data from the Federal Election Commission: Derek Willis
* Elections data from the Associated Press: Jacob Harris

And we'll also talk about:

* Your favorite dataset: You

We should also try to capture this background information. Between now and SRCCON, I'll get a GitHub repository up and running so people can contribute dataset tipsheets in simple way, even if they can't make the conference. Charlie Ornstein from ProPublica's already agreed to write up some background on using Medicare data even though he won't be at SRCCON. Let's help each other out like that and make something neat.
whoisthissessionfor: Anyone who works with data stories
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: data, knowing is half the battle

sessiontitle: The potential and tensions between science and data journalism
shortdescription:
There are lots of differences between journalism and research science. Scientists are largely writing for an audience of expert peers rather than the general public. They work on different time scales. They frequently design their own experiment and collect their own data, rather than inheriting data from a third party.

But, appropriately or not, there is a perception of data journalism as edging closer to science, in the forms of its analysis and in a trend towards collecting its own raw data. This is an intriguing trend but also pretty dangerous; data journalism can wind up carrying the veneer of scientific rigor without the real thing.

Let's talk about it. Subtopics may include:

-Should/can journalists better adopt the norms of the scientific community (openness, peer review, reproducibility, incremental discovery, uncertainty)? If so, how can we accomplish that without sacrificing other priorities?
-Experiment-driven journalism vs. retrospective analysis
-Citizen science initiatives
-Potential for closer partnerships between scientists and journalists on individual stories
-For mandatory symmetry in conference topics: what can scientists learn from journalists?
whoisthissessionfor: Anyone interested in science and in the methods and norms of the data journalism community

sessiontitle: There Is No CMS
shortdescription:
Anyone who’s written for the web has encountered content management systems: complex monoliths of templates, business rules and workflow that take words and media and transform them into the pages and articles our readers see. Anyone who has worked with these systems for long is also familiar with their flaws, their temperamental assumptions about the world, their frustrating constraints, their sometimes-incomprehensible syntax and controls. Even when they work well, they are monolithic systems that represent fossilizations of earlier processes, and are painful to augment and extend.

This session will be to convene a discussion about what’s wrong with CMSes -- both the systems themselves and the very concept of CMS -- and some possible solutions. What could be possible when we begin to think beyond the CMS as we know it? What systems or protocols could we create that might not be subject to the same problems and limitations? The New York Times R&D Lab will also present some early work showing what an (admittedly futuristic) alternative could look like.
whoisthissessionfor: Reporters, editors and producers who use CMSes; Developers, designers, and artists who’ve hacked / worked around a CMS to get their work published; Technologists who build and support these systems
anyprerequisites: Prior experience with, and strong opinions about, Content Management Systems
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: CMS, Content Management, Workflow, Invention, Spleen Venting

sessiontitle: Train Your Newsroom, Build an Army
shortdescription: At Mother Jones, we've successfully trained our newsroom in a suite of data and design skills. We have reporters and editors working in Illustrator, Photoshop, spreadsheets all on their own. Sounds impossible right? Here's how we've created a training program at Mother Jones that doesn't feel like a training program. We want to hear how other newsrooms are tackling training, and trade lessons learned, tips along the way.
whoisthissessionfor: All welcome

sessiontitle: Two Million Dollars and One Hour: Can We Design a New News Org that Doesn't Shit the Bed?
shortdescription: It's clear that there's demand for new approaches to news, so why have so many of the new news organizations fallen down after high-profile launches? Given the talent at SRCCON, can we sketch a new news organization that (1) produces high-quality news, (2) does it in new ways, and (3) is profitable? And can we do it in an hour.
whoisthissessionfor: people that care about news

sessiontitle: Using Web Type: Pitfalls and Workarounds
shortdescription:
The use of custom typefaces are commonplace online, but it still doesn’t just work. This session will be an overview of the different situations where things can behave differently from what you’d expect and how to deal with them.

- Font stacks and consistent type size
- Loading webfonts synchronously vs asynchronously
- Unicode and selective glyph removal
- Text rasterization on Windows: GDI vs DirectWrite
- Different antialiasing modes, type “bleeding” and white type on dark backgrounds
- New OpenType features available to web browsers
- Using SVG together with webfonts
whoisthissessionfor: Designers, developers

sessiontitle: What is our role in the open data movement?
shortdescription:
Open data is an idea gaining traction in local governments, with cities in particular beginning to craft legislation and embrace policies that could make public information much easier to acquire.

A great example of that movement is here in Pennsylvania. The city of Philadelphia hired a chief data officer in 2012 and has been steadily releasing public data sets through opendataphilly.org over the past few years. This spring, the city of Pittsburgh took steps to follow that lead, passing an open data ordinance and even more recently hiring a data coordinator to help city departments build an open data catalog and begin its release of information. 

I’m interested in having a conversation about what our role, as journalists/news organizations, should be in this effort. 

A couple of topics worth exploring: 

* What should our relationship be with the tech communities / open data enthusiasts? We are experienced at working with government data and understand the challenges, pitfalls and potential power of using it to tell stories about our communities. Should we be lending our expertise and partnering with open data groups? Or should we remain independent observers and fact-checkers of their work, treating them as another beat to cover? What are the pros and cons?

* The open data groups have already proven to be a powerful lobby on behalf of freedom of information laws. How should we work with them to ensure that local and state laws continue to be friendly and more open? On the flip side, how should we prepare to mitigate the risks of more restrictive laws being enacted if an open data experiment goes wrong (i.e., backlash against certain information being published or interpreted and published incorrectly?) 

* Related to all of the above: If we talk of partnering, what are the ways we can balance our business interests with the open data ethos?
whoisthissessionfor: Everyone
keywordstagsforyourproposaltopic: Freedom of Information, open data, FOIA, local government data

sessiontitle: Who are we missing?
shortdescription: There are people who aren't at SRCCON this year who should be here in a year or two. How do we bring them in? This will be a fact-finding session dedicated to articulating pathways into data journalism and newsroom code. What skills do people need? What are the various avenues in to the field? What resources are available to help newcomers? Or, what resources are lacking? Most importantly, how do we make this a welcome space for people with different backgrounds and experiences?
whoisthissessionfor: Everybody
